subject: Re: Reporting historical test results
msgSnippet: Hello Dianne, in a current project we had the need to identify new failed testcases in opposite to already known failed testcases. So we do the following: - a
messageBody:
Hello Dianne,

in a current project we had the need to identify new failed testcases
in opposite to already known failed testcases. So we do the following:

- a status-method (returning a string) is introduced into each
testcases (this is not necessary, but helpful)
- a java-program scans the testcases, generates an omitted list (not
ready, run manual etc) as csv and generates suites for the testcases
(based on package names)
- another javaprogram (lets call it the runner) starts the tests,
beginning with the "anchor"-suite - there is no graphical output
(could probably done with a listener)
- the runner loads the saved result of the previous test run (refer to
below)
- the runner compares the result of the current run (which gives also
information like total numbers of testcases, failed testcases, runtime
etc) with the previous run
- remark: the result contains the same information which is available
in the gui-runner and probably in xml-reports
- If a current failure is not found in the previous list, then it gets
the status new (this works also for different errors for the same
testcase)
- the runner saves the new result as csv (status, class, failure,
exception) under a fixed name as reference for the next run and
additionally archives it with a timestamp

The result of this process is:
- the omitted list tells us how much work is left (it is also archived
with a timestamp, but this history is needed not that often)
- the overall statistics of the testrun tells us how much work ist
done <g>
- the testresults gives us a list of failures to work on and most
important the newly introduced errors get the status new - to be
checked immediately
- a simple textsearch on the archive-directory reveals the history of
a testcase (when and how did he show up in the failure-history)
- by copying and renaming an archived result we can run the current
tests against any historical result (daily regression versus weekly
build for example)

I manually import the csv-files and the statistical information into a
spreadsheet with three tabs: omitted, failed, regression history
(charts with the overall numbers, especially the number of "new"
errors). At least the creation of the csv-data is no problem (the
complete set of information is available) and the import could be
semi-automized with a macro - I have not figured out how to insert an
excel-row directly from java. The only thing I would like to add is to
save the eclipse-logfile as well, but I do not know how ...

To me the important thing is to keep the historical data and to see
immediately when a testcase fails. In theory everything is green and
if not it is fixed before the next run ... at least thats what the
theory says <g>. Maybe you can use and extend this approach to extract
and excel the data you need.

cheers, Carsten


--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, didoss@c... wrote:
> Not hearing anyone running forward with a solution, I'm left with
two questions: one for the group, and one for some 'higher up'.
>
> For the group: do you think that this would be useful functionality
for someone to try and creat?
>
> For some 'higher up': if I were interested in writing this code,
what is the process for that?
>
> thanks, Dianne
>
> -------------- Original message --------------
>
> Paul Dominic writes:
>
> If you are generating JUnit Report through Ant,
> definitely you
> should write one build.xml file. Before generating new report,
> why not you
> take copy of the previous report. In Ant API contains copy
tag
> and move
> tag. So
> first step you take a back up using Copy/ Move tag.
> Second step you clear your old report using delete tag.
> Third step create report folder again.
> Finally you generate new report.
>
> Are you saying there's no extension for JUnit that sends the test
> results/report into a database, using JDBC or some other mechanism?
I'm
> new to JUnit, too, but I find it hard to believe that there isn't
> already software to store historical test results in a database.
>
>
> Todd.
>
>
>
>
